description: From Middle English acerteynen, from Old French acertener, from a- (“to, towards”) + certener (“make sure of”), from the adjective certain, from Latin certus (“certain, fixed”). Compare to Spanish acertar.

verbs.description: ascertain (third-person singular simple present ascertains, present participle ascertaining, simple past and past participle ascertained)

entries.meaning: To find out definitely; to discover or establish.
examples: Synonyms: determine, discover, establish, find out, learn, work out
As soon as we ascertain what the situation is, we can plan how to proceed.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To make (someone) certain or confident about something; to inform.
